aws::graph::propositions: # Piper PA-25 Aircraft Ditching in Atlantic Ocean Near Westerly, Rhode Island
Piper PA-25 aircraft with registration N7313Z was registered to Simmons Aviation.
Piper PA-25 aircraft with registration N7313Z was operated by Simmons Aviation.
The incident occurred on July 23, 2012, at 1502 eastern daylight time.
The aircraft was substantially damaged following a forced landing into the Atlantic Ocean.
The forced landing occurred near Westerly, Rhode Island.
The pilot was a certificated airline transport pilot.
The pilot was not injured in the incident.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the incident.
No flight plan was filed for the local flight.
The flight originated from Westerly State Airport in Westerly, Rhode Island.
Westerly State Airport has the identifier WST.
The flight departed at approximately 1445 eastern daylight time.
The flight was a banner tow operation.
The flight was conducted under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The pilot departed with 25 gallons of fuel for a 45-minute flight.
The pilot had not taken on any fuel on the day of the incident.
Approximately 12 minutes into the flight, the engine began running roughly.
The aircraft was flying at an altitude of about 600 feet when engine problems began.
The engine sounded as though it misfired.
After about 20 seconds, the pilot responded by increasing engine power to full.
The pilot richened the mixture in response to the engine problem.
The pilot applied carburetor heat in response to the engine problem.
Shortly after the pilot's actions, the engine experienced a total loss of power.
The loss of engine power was the defining event of the incident.
The pilot ditched the airplane into the ocean with the banner still attached.
The ditching location was approximately 6 miles from shore.
The pilot transmitted a distress call after the ditching.
The pilot was later rescued by a civilian boat.
The airplane was recovered from the ocean on July 31, 2012.
The pilot performed a cursory examination of the engine after recovery.
The pilot noted that the crankshaft was free to rotate after recovery.
Oil was present within the engine case after recovery.
The pilot reported an unspecified problem with a valve of the number 4 cylinder.
The pilot was unable to check operation of the magnetos because they were saturated with water.
An unspecified quantity of fuel was found in a fuel tank after recovery.
Due to damage from salt water immersion, no further examination of the engine was possible.
The pilot had most recently purchased fuel from a fixed base operator at Westerly State Airport.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| | |
| --- | --- |
| Enroute | Loss of engine power (total) (Defining event) |
| Emergency descent | Ditching |

On July 23, 2012, at 1502 eastern daylight time, a Piper PA-25, N7313Z, registered to and operated by Simmons Aviation, was substantially damaged following a forced landing into the Atlantic Ocean, near Westerly, Rhode Island. The certificated airline transport certificated pilot was not injured. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time and no flight plan was filed for the local flight, which originated from Westerly State Airport (WST), Westerly, Rhode Island, about 1445. The banner tow flight was conducted under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.

The pilot stated that he departed with 25 gallons of fuel for a 45-minute flight, and had not taken on any fuel that day. About 12 minutes into the flight, and while flying at an altitude of about 600 feet, the engine began running "roughly" and sounded as though it misfired. After about 20 seconds, the pilot responded by increasing engine power to full, richening the mixture, and applying carburetor heat. Shortly after, the engine experienced a total loss of power. The pilot subsequently ditched the airplane into the ocean with the banner still attached, approximately 6 miles from shore. The pilot transmitted a distress call, and was later rescued by a civilian boat.

The airplane was recovered from the ocean on July 31, 2012. The pilot performed a cursory examination of the engine and noted that the crankshaft was free to rotate, and oil was present within the engine case. The pilot reported that there was an unspecified "problem" with a valve of the number 4 cylinder, and that he was unable to check operation of the magnetos since they were saturated with water. An unspecified quantity of fuel was found in a fuel tank. Due to the extent of damage related to immersion in salt water, no further examination of the engine was possible.

The pilot had most recently purchased fuel from a fixed base operator at WST.
